entry.title: Another garbage SPFL/SKY deal imminent
entry.summary:
Photo by Craig Williamson/SNS Group via Getty Images
Almost Friday, and what better way to end the week with news that Neil ‘useless’ Doncaster is at it again, commissioning another abysmal deal with SKY.
SPFL and Sky discussing new £29.5m TV deal to show 60 Premiership matches | By @mrewanmurray https://t.co/ZcwBF1Tw4h— Guardian sport (@guardian_sport) August 11, 2022
Sky’s existing deal with the SPFL, which allows a maximum of 48 games a season, is due to expire in 2025. Under the revised terms, Sky will continue with that limit this season and next at a cost of £25.7m and £26.7m respectively. From the 2024-25 season the 60-match limit triggers a £27.6m payment which will increase by almost £2m for the next four seasons. Sky will have the option of further 10-match SPFL bundles at the cost of around £4m from 2024-5. In each of the past two seasons Sky have opted to stop well short of showing 48 live matches; with the new commitment, their contracted minimum would rise to 42. With 60 games would come the option to visit each top-flight club’s ground five times, as opposed to the current maximum of four. The deal still falls well short of the likes of Norway’s TV deal and the smaller clubs in the league will, once again, be suffering although no doubt Celtic fans moaning about this and actually showing concern will be, as per, scoffed at by the very fans of the clubs who this deal jeapordises. The outrage for this was made clear by many other fans earlier this evening
£29.5m per season for 60 matches. That's £492k per match.Current deal is £25.7m per season (and rising for next season) for 48 matches. That's £535k per match.Terrific work, guys. https://t.co/dqo3GGwQta— Steven Mill (@stevenmill) August 11, 2022
It's actually incredible how clueless Neil Doncaster is, completely under selling our game https://t.co/HwgZSDWWwh— Matt ☭ (sé/é) (@matts_408) August 11, 2022
Do we know if the clubs/SPFL board are able to block this?Tying into a deal, only worth a few million more a year than is currently in place, until 2029 in a rapidly changing landscape of live football would be a huge mistake. https://t.co/FFQIO1bS7b— Alexander Staff (@strider80) August 11, 2022
The SPFL have united Scottish football in condemnation of this potential shocker. Perhaps their only feat of note. https://t.co/ERotbG7Njk— Jonny McFarlane (@jonnyrmcfarlane) August 11, 2022
Embarrassing. https://t.co/IY2DonWfPV pic.twitter.com/v27BIOkv8M— Ryan Gilbert (@RyanGilbert79) August 11, 2022
Despite the moans and the tweets, this will happen and once again, Neil Doncaster will get away his negligence and undersell Scottish football YET AGAIN. The man is, genuinely, a scourge on the game here.

entry.title: Celtic ‘in’ for Collado - Sky Reports
entry.summary:
Photo by Jose Breton/Pics Action/NurPhoto via Getty Images
Well, it’s a midfielder we’re linked with again, albeit another attacking one and not the defensive king. Indeed, reports suggest Celtic are interested in Barcelona’s Alex Collado.
☘️Celtic have made an enquiry for Barcelona attacking midfielder Alex Collado — Sky Sports Scotland (@ScotlandSky) August 9, 2022
There may very well be ‘something’ to this, but let’s not get too excited and go ‘all in’ on it like we did with that Vinicius Souza nonsense, only to all get disappointed and in some cases, a few people looked really stupid. Furthermore, it would suggest Ange is keen to add more creativity to the squad, and may very well not be fully happy with the current attacking players in the side. Here’s some stats on Collado:
Celtic Transfer Link: Stats Report Álex Collado12 p90s in La Liga - mostly central/att mid but also some games on right wing. Overall, a roughly average data output - Granada relegated so team quality influence some numbers.High dribble volume and effective tackler. pic.twitter.com/NrCtzpExAE— The Cynic (@90MinuteCynic) August 9, 2022
And no article would be complete without a youtube compilation and various readers declaring him the new Toni Kroos or De Bruyne so here we are:
